about: Richard Wilhelm was a German translator. He translated many philosophical works from Chinese into German that in turn have been translated into other major languages of the world, including English. His translation of the I Ching is still regarded as one of the finest, as is his translation of The Secret of the Golden Flower, both of which include introductions by Swiss psychologist Carl Jung, who was a personal friend.

Jung proposed and developed the concepts of extraversion and introversion; archetypes, and the collective unconscious. about:

about: Greg Call is an American artist and book illustrator, best known for the artwork he did for the Starcatchers fantasy series for young readers. Born and raised in Colorado, he was educated at the Colorado Institute of Art in Denver, where he subsequently worked, as well as at The Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, California. about:
Geraldine McCaughrean was born in 1951 and brought up in North London. She has written over 120 books, 50 short plays for schools, and a radio play.

about:
Sir James Matthew Barrie, 1st Baronet, OM was a Scottish author and dramatist, best remembered today as the creator of Peter Pan.

He took up journalism, worked for a Nottingham newspaper, and contributed to various London journals before moving to London in 1885. He also illustrated The Book of Ghosts, Where Fairies Dance, The Book of Wizards, and The Book of Fairy Poetry as well as wrote and illustrated the graphic novel in The Small. Michael lives with his wife, Kathleen, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.

about: John E. (Edwin) Woods is a translator who specializes in translating German literature, since about 1978. name: Christopher Marlowe
about:
Christopher "Kit" Marlowe (baptised 26 February 1564) was an English dramatist, poet and translator of the Elizabethan era. The foremost Elizabethan tragedian next to William Shakespeare, he is known for his magnificent blank verse, his overreaching protagonists, and his own mysterious and untimely death.

His essays, interviews, and reviews appear in the New York Times Book Review, among other publications. Leonard S. Marcus lives in Brooklyn.
